lg.l: I'Ve thought upon't; and cannot tell which way
Ought I can say now, should advance the Play.
For Playes are either good, or bad; the good,
(If they doe beg) beg to be understood.
And in good faith, that has as bold a sound,
As if a beggar should aske twentie pound.
— Men have it not about them:
Then (Gentlemen) if rightly understood,
The bad doe need lesse Prologue than the good:
For if it chance the Plot be lame, or blinde,
Ill cloath'd, deform'd throughout, it needs must finde
Compassion,— It is a beggar without Art:—
But it fals out in penny worths of Wit,
As in all bargaines else. Men ever get
All they can in; will have London measure,
A handful over in their verie pleasure.
And now yee have't; hee could not well deny'ee,
And I dare sweare hee's scarce a saver by yee.

lg.head: Prologue to the Court.
lg.l: THose common passions, hopes, and feares, that still,
The Poets first and then the Prologues fill
In this our age, hee that writ this, by mee,
Protests against as modest foolerie.
Hee thinks it an odd thing to be in paine,
For nothing else, but to be well againe.
Who writes to feare is so; had hee not writ;
You nere had been the Iudges of his wit;
And when hee had, did hee but then intend
To please himselfe, hee sure might have his end
Without th'expence of hope, and that hee had
That made this Play, although the Play be bad.
Then Gentlemen be thriftie, save your doomes
For the next man, or the next Play that comes;
For smiles are nothing, where men doe not care,
And frownes as little, where they need not feare.

lg.head: To the King.
lg.l: THis (Sir) to them, but unto Majestie.
All hee has said before, hee does denie.
Yet not to Majestie: that were to bring
His feares to be, but for the Queene and King,
Not for your selves; and that hee dares not say:
Y'are his Soveraignes another way:
Your soules are Princes, and you have as good
A title that way, as yee have by blood
To governe, and here your powers more great
And absolute, than in the royall Seat.
There men dispute, and but by Law obey,
Here is no Law at all, but what yee say.

list.item: THERSAMES, Prince, in love with Aglaura.
ORBELLA, Queene, at first Mistresse to Ziriff: in love with Ariaspes.
ZIRIFF, Otherwayes Sorannez disguised, Captaine of the Guard, in love with Orbella, brother to Aglaura.
JOLAS, A Lord of the Councell, seeming friend to the Prince, but a Traytour, in love with Semanthe.
AGLAURA, In love with the Prince, but nam'd Mistresse to the King.
ORSAMES, A young Lord antiplatonique; friend to the Prince.
SEMANTHE, In love with Ziriff; platonique.

div.head: SCENA I.

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: MArried? and in Diana's Grove!

sp.speaker: JOLIN.
sp.l: So was th'appointment, or my Sense deceiv'd me.

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: Married!
Now by those Powers that tye those prettie knots,
'tis verie fine, good faith 'tis wondrous fine:

sp.speaker: JOLIN.
sp.l: What is, Brother?

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: Why? to marrie Sister—
t'injoy 'twixt lawfull and unlawfull thus
a happinesse, steale as 'twere ones owne;
Diana's Grove, sayest thou?— Scratcheth his head.

sp.speaker: JOLIN.
sp.l: That's the place; the hunt once up, and all
ingag'd in the sport, they meane to leave
the company, and steale unto those thickets,
where, there's a Priest attends them;

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: And will they lye together, think'st thou?

sp.speaker: JOLIN.
sp.l: Is there distinction of sex thinke you?
or flesh and bloud?

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: True; but the King, Sister!

sp.speaker: JOLIN.
sp.l: But love, Brother!

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: Thou sayest well;
'tis fine, 'tis wondrous fine:
Diana's grove—

sp.speaker: JOLIN.
sp.l: Yes, Diana's grove,
but brother if you should speake of this now,—

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: Why thou know'st a drowning man holds not a thing so fast:
Semanthe! she shuns me too:

div.stage: Enter Semanthe, she sees Jolas, and goes in agen.

sp.speaker: JOLIN.
sp.l: The wound festred sure!
the hurt the boy gave her, when first
shee look'd abroad into the world, is not yet cur'd.

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: What hurt?

sp.speaker: JOLIN.
sp.l: Why, know you not
shee was in love long since with young Zorannes,
(Aglaura's brother,) and the now Queenes betroth'd?

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: Some such slight Tale I've heard.

sp.speaker: JOLIN.
sp.l: Slight? she yet does weepe, when she but heares him nam'd,
and tels the prettiest and the saddest stories
of all those civill wars, and those Amours,
That, trust me, both my Lady and my selfe
turne weping Statues still.

sp.speaker: JOLAS,
sp.l: Pish, 'tis not that.
'Tis Ziriff, and his fresh glories here
have robb'd me of her.
Since he thus appear'd in Court,
my love has languish'd worse than Plants in drought.
But time's a good Physician: come, lets in:
the King and Queene by this time are come forth.

sp.speaker: 1 SERV.
sp.l: Yonder's a crowd without, as if some strange sight
were to be seene to day here.

sp.speaker: 2 SERV.
sp.l: Two or three with Carbonadoes afore in stead of faces
mistooke the doore for a breach, and at the opening of it,
are striving still which should enter first.

sp.speaker: 3 SERV.
sp.l: Is my Lord busie?

div.stage: Enter Ziriff as in his Studie.

sp.speaker: 1 SERV.
sp.l: My Lord, there are some Souldiers without—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Well, I will dispatch them presently.

sp.speaker: 2 SERV.
sp.l: th'Embassadours from the Cadusians too—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Shew them the Gallerie.

sp.speaker: 3 SERV.
sp.l: One from the King—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Againe? I come, I come.
Greatnesse, thou vainer shadow of the Princes beames,
begot by meere reflection, nourish'd in extreames;
first taught to creepe, and live upon the glance,
poorely to fare, till thine owne proper strength
bring thee to surfet of thy selfe at last.
How dull a Pageant, would this States-play seeme
to mee now; were not my love and my revenge
mixt with it?—
Three tedious Winters have I waited here,
like patient Chymists blowing still the coales,
and still expecting, when the blessed houre
would come, should make me master of
the Court Elixar, Power, for that turnes all:
'tis in projection now; downe, sorrow, downe,
and swell my heart no more, and thou wrong'd ghost
of my dead father, to thy bed agen,
and sleepe securely;
it cannot now be long, for sure Fate must,
as't has beene cruell, so, a while be just.

div.stage: Enter King and Lords, the Lords intreating for Prisoners.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I say they shall not live; our mercie
would turne sinne, should we but use it er'e:
Pittie, and Love, the bosses onely be
of government, merely for shew and ornament.
Feare is the bit that mans proud will restraines,
and makes its vice its vertue— See it done.
sp.stage: Enter to them Queene, Aglaura, Ladies, the King addresses himselfe to Aglaura.
sp.l: So early, and so curious in your dresse, (faire Mistresse?)
these prettie ambushes and traps for hearts
set with such care to day, looke like designe:
speake, Lady, is't a massacre resolv'd?
is conquering one by one growne tedious sport?
or is the number of the taken such,
that for your safetie you must kill out-right?

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Did none doe greater mischiefe (Sir) than I,
heav'n would not much be troubled with sad storie,
nor would the quarrell man has to the Starres
be kept alive so strongly.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: When hee does leave't
woman must take it up, and justly too;
for robbing of the sex and giving all to you.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Their weaknesses you meane, and I confesse, Sir.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: The greatest subjects of their power or glorie.
Such gentle rape thou act'st upon my soule,
and with such pleasing violence dost force it still;
that when it should resist, it tamely yeilds,
making a kinde of haste to be undone,
as if the way to victorie were losse,
and conquest came by overthrow.

div.stage: Enter an Expresse delivering a Packet upon his knee.

sp.speaker: QU.
sp.l: Prettie!
sp.stage: The Queene looking upon a flower in one of the Ladies heads.
sp.l: Is it the child of nature, or of some faire hand?

sp.speaker: LA.
sp.l: 'Tis as the beautie Madam of some faces,
Arts issue onely.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Thersames,
This concernes you most, brought you her picture?

sp.speaker: EXP.
sp.l: Something made up for her in haste I have.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: If she does owe no part of this faire dower
unto the Painter, she is rich enough.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: A kinde of merrie sadnesse in this face
becomes it much.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: There is indeed, Aglaura,
a prettie sullennesse drest up in smiles,
that sayes this beautie can both kill, and save.
How like you her Thersames?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: As well as any man can doe a house
by seeing of the portall, here's but a face,
and faces (Sir) are things I have not studied;
I have my dutie, and may boldly sweare,
what you like best will ever please me most.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Spoke like Thersames, and my sonne,
come! the day holds faire,
let all the Hunts-men meet us in the vale,
we will uncouple there.

sp.speaker: ARIASP.
sp.l: How odd a thing a croud is unto me!
sure nature intended I should be alone,
had not that old doting man-mid-wife Time
slept, when he should have brought me forth, I had
beene so too—
To be borne neere, and onely neere a crowne—

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: How now my Lord?
what? walking o'th'tops of Pyramids?
whispering your selfe away
like a deny'd lover? come! to horse, to horse,
and I will shew you streight a sight shall please you
more than kinde lookes from her you dote upon
after a falling out.

sp.speaker: ARIASP.
sp.l: Prithee what is't?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Ile tell you as I goe.—

sp.speaker: HUNT.
sp.l: Which way? which way?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: This is the grove, 'tis somewhere here within.—

div.stage: Enter dogging of them, Ariaspes, Jolas.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Gently! Gently!

div.stage: Enter Orsames, Philan, a Huntsman, two Courtiers.

sp.speaker: HUNTS.
sp.l: No hurt, my Lord, I hope.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: None, none,
Thou wouldst have warranted it to another,
if I had broke my neck:
what? do'st thinke my horse and I shew tricks?
that which way soever he throwes me
like a Tumblers boy I must fall safe?
sp.p: was there a bed of roses there? would I were Eunuch if I had not as lief h'a falne in the state, as where I did, the ground was as hard, as if it had been pav'd with Platonicke Ladies hearts, and this unconscionable fellow askes whether I have no hurt; where's my horse?

sp.speaker: 1 COURT.
sp.l: Making love to the next mare I thinke.

sp.speaker: 2 COURT.
sp.l: Not the next I assure you,
Hee 's gallop't away, as if all the spurs i'th' field
were in his sides.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Why there's it: the jade's in the fashion too.
Now h'as done me an injurie, he will not come neere me.
Well when I hunt next, may it be upon a starv'd cow,
without a saddle too.
sp.p: And may I fall into a saw-pit, and not be taken up, but with suspition of having beene private, with mine owne beast there. Now I better consider on't too, Gentlemen, 'tis but the same thing we doe at Court; here's everie man striving who shall be formost, and hotly pursuing of what he seldome overtakes, or if he does, it's no great matter.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: He that's best hors'd (that is best friended) gets in soonest, and then all hee has to doe is to laugh at those that are behind. Shall we help you my Lord?—

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Prithee doe— stay!
To be in view, is to be in favour,
is it not?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Right,
sp.p: and he that has a strong faction against him, hunts upon a cold sent, and may in time come to a losse.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.p: Here's one rides two miles about, while another leapes a ditch and is in before him.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Where note the indirect way's the nearest.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Good againe—

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.p: And here's another puts on, and fals into a quagmire, (that is) followes the Court till he has spent all (for your Court quagmire is want of money) there a man is sure to stick, and then not one helps him out, if they doe not laugh at him.

sp.speaker: 1 COURT.
sp.p: What thinke you of him, that hunts after my rate and never sees the Deere?

sp.speaker: 2 COURT.
sp.p: Why hee is like some young fellow, that followes the Court, and never sees the King.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: To spurre a horse till he is tir'd, is

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: To importune a friend till he be wearie of you.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: For then upon the first occasion y'are throwne off, as I was now.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: This is nothing to the catching of your horse Orsames.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.p: Thou say'st true, I thinke he is no transmigrated Philosopher, and therefore not likely to be taken with moralls.
Gentlemen— your help, the next I hope will bee yours, and then 'twill bee my turne.—

div.stage: Enter againe married, Thersames, Aglaura, Priest.

sp.speaker: THER's.
sp.l: Feare not my Deare, if when Loves diet
was bare lookes and those stolne too,
he yet did thrive! what then
will he doe now? when everie night will be
a feast, and everie day fresh revelrie.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Will he not surfet, when he once shall come
to grosser fare (my Lord) and so grow sicke,
and Love once sicke, how quickly will it dye?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Ours cannot; 'tis as immortall as the things
that elemented it, which were our soules:
nor can they ere impaire in health, for what
these holy rites doe warrant us to doe,
more than our bodies would for quenching thirst.
Come let's to horse, we shall be mist,
for we are envies marke, and Court eyes carrie farre.
Your prayers and silence Sir:—

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: If it succeed? I weare thee here my Iolas—

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: If it succeed? will night succeed the day?
or houres one to another? is not his lust
the Idoll of his soule? and was not she
the Idoll of his lust? as safely he might
have stolne the Diadem from off his head,
and he would lesse have mist it.
You now, my Lord, must raise his jealousie,
teach it to looke through the false opticke feare,
and make it see all double: Tell him the Prince
would not have thus presum'd, but that he does
intend worse yet; and that his crowne and life
will be the next attempt.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Right, and I will urge
how dangerous 'tis unto the present state,
To have the creatures, and the followers
of the next Prince (whom all now strive to please)
too neere about him:

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: What if the male-contents that use
to come unto him were discovered?

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: By no meanes; for 'twere in vaine to give
him discontent (which too must needs be done)
if they within him gave't not nourishment.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Well, Ile away first for the print's too big
if we be seene together.—

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: I have so fraught this Barke with hope, that it
dares venture now in any storme, or weather;
and if hee sinke or splits, all's one to me.
" Ambition seemes all things, and yet is none,
" but in disguise stalkes to opinion
" and fooles it into faith, for everie thing:
'Tis not with th'ascending to a Throne,
As 'tis with staires, and steps, that are the same;
For to a Crowne, each humor's a degree;
and as men change, and differ, so must wee.
The name of vertue doth the people please,
not for their love to vertue, but their case,
and Parrat Rumour I that tale have taught.
By making love I hold the womans grace,
'tis the Court double key, and entrance gets
to all the little plots; the fierie spirits
my love to Armes hath drawne into my faction;
all, but the minion of the Time, is mine,
and he shall be, or shall not be at all.
He that beholds a wing in pieces torne,
and knowes not that to heav'n it once did beare
the high-flowne and selfe-less'ning bird, will think
and call them idle Subjects of the winde:
when he that has the skill to imp and binde
these in right places, will thus truth discover;
That borrowed Instruments doe oft convey
the Soule to her propos'd Intents, and where
our Stars deny, Art may supply—

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: Thinke you it is not then
the little jealousies (my Lord) and feares,
joy mixt with doubt, and doubt reviv'd with hope
that crownes all love with pleasure? these are lost
when once wee come to full fruition;
like waking in the morning when all night
on fancie has beene fed with some new strange delight.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: I grant you, Madam, that the feares, and joyes,
hopes, and desires, mixt with despaires, and doubts,
doe make the sport in love; that they are
the verie dogs by which we hunt the hare;
but as the dogs would stop, and streight give o're
were it not for the little thing before;
so would our passions; both alike must be
flesh't in the chase.

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.l: Will you then place the happinesse, but there,
where the dull plow man and the plow-mans horse
can finde it out? Shall soules refin'd, not know
how to preserve alive a noble flame,
but let it die, burne out to appetite?

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: Love's a Chamelion, and would live on aire,
Physick for agues, starving is his food.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Why? there's it now! a greater Epicure
lives not on earth; my Lord and I have beene
in 's privie kitchin, seene his bills of Fare.

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: And how, and how my Lord?

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: A mightie Prince,
and full of curiositie— Harts newly slaine
serv'd up intire, and stucke with little Arrowes
in stead of Cloves—

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Sometimes a cheeke plumpt up
with broth, with creame and clarret mingled
for sauce, and round about the dish
Pomegranate kernells, strew'd on leaves of Lillies.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Then will he have black eies, for those of late
he feeds on much, and for varietie
the gray—

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: You forget his cover'd dishes
of Iene-strayes, and Marmalade of lips,
perfum'd by breath sweet as the beanes first blossomes.

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: Rare!
And what's the drinke to all this meat, my Lord?

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Nothing but pearle dissolv'd, teares still fresh, fetch'd
from Lovers eyes, which if they come to be
warme in the carriage, are streight cool'd with sighs.

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: And all this rich proportion, perchance
we would allow him:

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: True! but therefore this is but his common dinner;
onely serves
when his chiefe Cookes, Liking and Opportunitie,
are out o'th' way; for when hee feasts indeed,
'tis there, where the wise people of the world
did place the vertues, i'th' middle— Madam.

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.l: My Lord, there is so little hope we should convert you;
and if we should, so little got by it,
that wee'll not lose so much upon't as sleepe.
Your Lordships servants—

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Nay Ladies wee'll wait upon you to your chambers.

sp.speaker: PH.
sp.l: Prithee lets spare the complement, we shall doe no good.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: By this hand Ile try,
they keepe me fasting, and I must be praying.

div.stage: Aglaura undressing of her selse, Jolina.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Undresse mee:—
Is it not late, Iolina?
it was the longest day, this—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Softly, as Death it selfe comes on,
when it does steale away the sicke mans breath,
and standers by perceive it not,
have I trod the way unto these lodgings.
How wisely doe those Powers
that give us happinesse, order it?
sending us still feares to bound our joyes,
which else would over-flow and lose themselves:
see where shee sits,
like Day retir'd into another world.
Deare mine! where all the beautie man admires
in scattered pieces, does united lye.
Where sense does feast, and yet where sweet desire
lives in its longing, like a misers eye,
that never knew, nor saw sacietie:
tell me, by what approaches must I come
to take in what remaines of my felicitie?

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Needs there any new ones, where the breach
is made already? you are entred here—
long since (Sir) here, and I have giv'n up all.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: All but the Fort, and in such wars, as these,
till that be yeilded up, there is no peace,
nor triumph to be made; come! undoe, undoe,
and from these envious clouds slide quicke
into Loves proper Sphere, thy bed:
The wearie traveller, whom the busie Sunne
hath vex't all day, and scortch'd almost to tinder,
nere long'd for night, as I have long'd for this.
What rude hand is that?
Goe Iolina, see, but let none enter—

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: 'Tis Ziriff, Sir.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: — Oh—
Something of weight hath falne out it seemes,
which in his zeale he could not keepe till morning.
But one short minute, Deare, into that chamber.—
How now?
thou start'st, as if thy sinnes had met thee,
or thy Fathers ghost; what newes man?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Such as will send the blood of hastie messages
unto the heart, and make it call
all that is man about you into councell;
where's the Princesse, Sir?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Why? what of her?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: The King must have her—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: The King must have her (Sir)

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Though feare of worse makes ill, still relish better,
and this looke handsome in our friendship, Ziriff,
yet so severe a preparation—,
there needed not: come, come! what ist?
sp.stage: Ziriff leads him to the doore, and shewes him a Guard.
sp.l: A Guard! Thersames,
thou art lost; betray'd
by faithlesse and ungratefull man,
out of a happinesse:—
sp.stage: He steps betweene the doore and him, and drawes.
sp.l: the verie thought of that,
will lend my anger so much noble justice,
that wert thou master of as much fresh life,
as th'ast beene of villany, it should not serve,
nor stocke thee out, to glorie, or repent
the least of it.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Put up: put up! such unbecomming anger
I have not seene you weare before.
What? draw upon your friend,
doe you beleeve me right now?—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: I scarce beleeve mine eyes:— Zorannes.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: The same, but how preserv'd, or why
thus long disguis'd to you, a freer houre must speake:
That y'are betraid is certaine, but by whom,
unlesse the Priest himselfe, I cannot ghesse
more than the marriage, though he knowes not of:
if you now send her on these early summons
before the sparks are growne into a flame,
you doe redeeme th'offence, or make it lesse;
and (on my life) yet his intents are faire,
and he will but besiege, not force affection.
So you gaine time; if you refuse, there's but
one way; you know his power and passion.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Into how strange a labyrinth am I
now falne! what shall I doe Zorannes?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Doe (Sir) as Sea-men, that have lost their light
and way: strike saile, and lye quiet a while.
Your forces in the Province are not yet
in readinesse, nor is our friend Zephines
arriv'd at Delphos; nothing is ripe, besides—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Good heavens, did I but dreame that she was mine?
upon imagination did I climbe up to
this height? let mee then wake and dye,
some courteous hand snatch mee from what's to come,
and ere my wrongs have being, give them end:

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: How poore, and how unlike the Prince is this?
this trifle woman does unman us all;
robs us so much, it makes us things of pittie.
Is this a time to loose our anger in?
and vainly breathe it out? when all wee have
will hardly fill the saile of Resolution,
and make us beare up high enough for action.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: I have done (Sir) pray chide no more;
the slave whom tedious custome has enur'd
and taught to thinke of miserie as of food,
counting it but a necessarie of life,
and so digesting it, shall not so much as once
be nam'd to patience, when I am spoken of:
marke mee; for I will now undoe my selfe
as willingly, as virgins give up all first nights
to them they love:—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Stay, Sir, 'twere fit Aglaura yet were kept
in ignorance: I will dismisse the Guard,
and be my selfe againe.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: In how much worse estate am I in now,
Than if I nere had knowne her; privation,
is a miserie as much above bare wretchednesse,
as that is short of happinesse:
So when the Sunne does not appeare,
'Tis darker 'cause it once was here.

div.stage: Enter Ziriff speakes to Orsames and others halfe entred.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Nay, Gentlemen:
there needs no force, where there is no resistance:
Ile satisfie the King my selfe.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: — Oh 'tis well y'are come,
there was within me fresh Rebellion,
and reason was almost unking'd agen.
But you shall have her Sir—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: What doubtfull combats in this noble youth
passion and reason have!—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Here Sir—

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: What meanes the Prince, my Lord?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Madam, his wiser feare has taught him to disguise
his love, and make it looke a little rude at parting.
Affaires that doe concerne, all that you hope from
happinesse, this night force him away:
and lest you should have tempted him to stay,
(Which hee did doubt you would and would prevaile)
he left you thus: he does desire by mee
you would this night lodge in the little towre,
which is in my command; the reasons why
himselfe will shortly tell you.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: 'Tis strange, but I am all Obedience—

div.head: SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter Thersames, Jolas a Lord of the Counsell.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: I told him so, Sir, urg'd 'twas no common knot,
that to the tying of it two powerfull Princes,
Vertue and Love were joyn'd, and that
a greater than these two was now
ingaged in it; Religion; but 'twould not doe,
the corke of passion boy'd up all reason so
that what was said, swam but o'th'top of th'eare
nere reach't the heart:

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Is there no way for Kings to shew their power,
but in their Subjects wrongs? no subject neither
but his owne sonne?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Right Sir:
no quarrie for his lust to gorge on, but on what
you fairely had flowne at, and taken:
well— wert not the King, or wert indeed
not you, that have such hopes, and such a crowne
to venter, and yet—
tis but a woman.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.p: How? that but againe, and thou arr more injurious than hee, and woul't provoke me sooner.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Why Sir?
there are no altars yet addrest unto her,
nor sacrifice; if I have made her lesse
than what she is, it was my love to you:
For in my thoughts, and here within, I hold her
the noblest peece Nature ere lent our eyes,
and of the which, all women else, are but
weake counterfeits, made up by her journey-men:
but was this fit to tell you?
I know you value but too high all that,
and in a losse we should not make things more,
tis miseries happinesse, that wee can make it lesse
by art, throw a forgetfulnesse upon our ills,
Yet who can doe it here?
when everie voyce, must needs, and everie face,
by shewing what she was not, shew what she was.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Ile instantly unto him—

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Stay Sir
Though't be the utmost of my Fortunes hope
to have an equall share of ill with you:
yet I could wish we sold this trifle life,
at a farre dearer rate, than we are like to doe,
since ' tis a King's the Merchant.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Ha!
King, I! 'tis indeed,
and there's no Art can cancell that high bond:

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: — Hee cooles againe.—
True Sir, and yet mee thinks to know a reason—
for passive nature nere had glorious end,
and he that States preventions ever learn'd,
knowes, 'tis one motion to strike and to defend.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.l: Some of the Lords without, and from the King.
they say, wait you.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: What subtle State tricke now?
but one turne here, and I am back my Lord.—

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: This will not doe; his resolution's like
a skilfull horse-man, and reason is the stirrop,
which though a sudden shock may make
it loose, yet does it meet it handsomely agen.
Stay, 'tmust be some sudden feare of wrong
to her, that may draw on a sudden act
from him, and ruine from the King; for such
a spirit will not like common ones, be
rais'd by everie spell, 'tis in loves circle
onely 'twill appeare.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: I cannot beare the burthen of my wrongs
one minute longer.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Why! what's the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: They doe pretend the safetie of the State
now, nothing but my marriage with Cadusia
can secure th'adjoyning countrey to it;
confinement during life for me if I refuse
Diana's Nunnerie for her— And at that Nunn'rie, Iolas,
allegiance in mee like the string of a watch
wound up too high, and forc'd above the nicke,
ran backe, and in a moment was unravell'd all.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Now by the love I beare to Justice,
That Nunn'rie was too severe; when vertuous love's a crime
what man can hope to scape a punishment,
or who's indeed so wretched to desire it?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Right!

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: What answer made you, Sir?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: None, they gave me till to morrow,
and ere that be, or they or I
must know our destinie:
come friend let's in, there is no sleeping now;
for time is short, and we have much to doe.—

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.p: Judge you, Gentlemen, if I be not as unfortunate as a gamester thinks himselfe upon the losse
sp.l: of the last stake; this is the first she
I ever swore to heartily, and (by those eyes)
I thinke I had continued unperjur'd a whole moneth,
(and that's faire you'll say.)

sp.speaker: 1 COURT.
sp.l: Verie faire—

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Had she not run mad betwixt.—

sp.speaker: 2 COURT.
sp.l: How? mad?
who? Semanthe?

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Yea, yea, mad, aske Philan else.
people that want cleere intervalls talkenot
sp.p: so wildly: Ile tell you Gallants; 'tis now, since first I found my selfe a little bot, and quivering 'bout the heart, some ten dayes since, (a tedious Ague) Sirs; (but what of that?)
sp.l: the gratious glance, and little whisper past,
approaches made from th'hand unto the lip,
I came to visit her, and (as you know we use)
breathing a sigh or two by way of prologue,
told her, that in Loves Physicke 'twas a rule,
where the disease had birth to seeke a cure;
I had no sooner nam'd love to her, but she
began to talke of Flames, and Flames,
neither devouring, nor devour'd, of Aire,
and of Camelions—

sp.speaker: 1 COURT.
sp.l: Oh the Platoniques.

sp.speaker: 2 COURT.
sp.p: Those of the new religion in love! your Lordship's merrie, troth, how doe you like the humor on't?

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: As thou would'st like red haire, or leannesse
in thy Mistresse; scurvily, ' tdoes worse with handsomnesse,
than strong desire would doe with impotence;
a meere tricke to inhance the price of kisses—

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Sure these silly women, when they feed
our expectation so high, doe but like
ignorant Conjurers, that raise a Spirit
which handsomly they cannot lay againe:

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: True, 'tis like some that nourish up
sp.p: young Lions till they grow so great, they are affraid of themselves, they dare not grant at last,
sp.l: for feare they should not satisfie.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Who's for the Towne? I must take up againe,

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.p: This villanous Love's as chargeable as the Philosophers Stone, and thy Mistresse as hard to compasse too!

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: The Platonique is ever so; they are as tedious
before they come to the point, as an old man
fall'n into the Stories of his youth;

sp.speaker: 2. COUR.
sp.l: Or a widow into the praises of her first husband.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Well, if she hold out but one moneth longer,
if I doe not quite forget, I ere beleaguer'd there,
and remove the siege to another place, may all
the curses beguil'd virgins lose upon their perjur'd Lovers
fall upon mee.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: And thou woult deserve'em all.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: For being in the company of those
that tooke away the Prince's Mistresse from him.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Peace, that will be redeem'd—
I put but on this wildnesse to disguise my selfe;
there are brave things in hand, hearke i'thy eare:—

sp.speaker: 1. COURT.
sp.l: Some severe plot upon a maiden-head.
These two young Lords make love,
as Embroyderers worke against a Maske, night and day;
They thinke importunitie a neerer way than merit,
and take women as Schoole-boyes catch Squirrells.
hunt 'em up and downe till they are wearie,
and fall downe before'em.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Who loves the Prince failes not—

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: And I am one: my injuries are great as thine,
and doe perswade as strongly.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: I had command to bring thee,
faile not and in thine owne disguise

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Why in disguise?

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: It is the Princes policie and love;
for if wee should miscarrie,
some one taken might betray the rest
unknowne to one another,
each man is safe, in his owne valour;

sp.speaker: 2. COURT.
sp.p: And what Mercers wife are you to cheapen now in stead of his silks?

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.p: Troth; 'tis not so well; 'tis but a Cozen of thine— come Philan let's along:—

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: What is it thus within whispering remorse,
and calls Love Tyrant? all powers, but his,
their rigour, and our feare, have made divine!
But everie Creature holds of him by sense,
the sweetest Tenure; yea! but my husbands brother:
and what of that? doe harmlesse birds or beasts
aske leave of curious Heraldrie at all?
Does not the wombe of one faire spring,
bring unto the earth many sweet rivers,
that wantonly doe one another chace,
and in one bed, kisse, mingle, and embrace?
Man (Natures heire) is not by her will ti'de,
to shun all creatures are alli'd unto him,
for then hee should shun all; since death and life
doubly allies all them that live by breath:
The Aire that does impart to all lifes brood,
refreshing, is so neere to it selfe, and to us all,
that all in all is individuall:
But, how am I sure one and the same desire
warmes Ariaspes: for Art can keepe alive
a beddred love.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Alone, (Madam) and overcast with thought,
uncloud— uncloud— for if wee may beleeve
the smiles of Fortune, love shall no longer pine
in prison thus, nor undelivered travell
with throes of feare, and of desire about it.
The Prince, (like to a valiant beast in nets)
striving to force a freedome suddenly,
has made himselfe at length, the surer prey:
the King stands only now betwixt, and is,
just like a single tree, that hinders all the prospect:
'tis but the cutting downe of him, and wee—

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: Why would't thou thus imbarque into strange seas,
and trouble Fate, for what wee have already?
Thou art to mee what thou now seek'st, a Kingdome;
and were thy love as great, as thy ambition;
I should be so to thee.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Thinke you, you are not Madam?
as well and justly may you doubt the truths,
tortur'd, or dying men doe leave behinde them:
but then my fortune turnes my miserie,
when my addition shall but make you lesse;
shall I endure that head that wore a crowne,
for my sake should weare none? First let mee lose
th'exchequer of my wealth, your love; nay, may
all that rich Treasurie you have about you,
be rifled by the man I hated, and I looke on;
though youth be full of sinne, and heav'n be just,
so sad a doome I hope they keepe not from me;
Remember what a quicke Apostacie he made,
when all his vowes were up to heav'n and you.
How, ere the Bridall torches were burnt out,
his flames grew weake, and sicklier; thinke on that,
thinke how unsafe you are, if she should now,
not sell her honour at a lower rate,
than your place in his bed.

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: And would not you prove false too then?

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: By this— and this— loves break-fast:
by his feasts too yet to come, by all the
beautie in this face, divinitie too great
to be prophan'd—

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: O doe not sweare by that;
Cankers may eat that flow'r upon the stalke,
(for sicknesse and mischance, are great devourers)
and when there is not in these cheeks and lips,
left red enough to blush at perjurie,
when you shall make it, what shall I doe then?

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Our soules by that time (Madam)
will by long custome so acquainted be,
they will not need that duller truch-man Flesh,
but freely, and without those poorer helps,
converse and mingle; meane time wee'll teach
our loves to speake, not thus to live by signes,
and action is his native language, Madam,
this box but open'd to the Sense will doe't.

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: I undertake I know not what,

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Thine owne safetie (Dearest)
let it be this night, if thou do'st;
love thy selfe or mee.

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: That's verie sudden.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Not if wee be so, and we must now be wise,
For when their Sunne sets, ours begins to rise.—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Then all my feares are true, and shee is false;
false as a falling Star, or Glow-wormes fire:
This Devill Beautie is compounded strangely,
It is a subtill point, and hard to know,
whether't has in't more active tempting,
or more passive tempted; so soone it forces,
and so soone it yeelds—
Good Gods! shee seiz'd my heart, as if from you
sh'ad had Commission to have us'd mee so;
and all mankinde besides— and see, if the just Ocean
makes more haste to pay
to needy rivers, what it borrow'd first,
then shee to give, where shee nere tooke;
mee thinks I feele anger, Revenges harbenger
chalking up all within, and thrusting out
of doores, the tame and softer passions;—
It must be so:
To love is noble frailtie, but poore sin
When wee fall once to Love, unlov'd agen.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: 'Twere fit your Justice did consider, (Sir)
what way it tooke; if you should apprehend
the Prince for Treason (which hee never did)
and which, unacted, is unborne; (at least will be beleev'd so)
lookers on, and the loud talking croud,
will thinke it all but water colours
laid on for a time,
and which wip'd off, each common eye would see,
Strange ends, through stranger wayes:

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Think'st thou I will compound with Treason then?
and make one feare anothers Advocate?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Vertue forbid Sir, but if you would permit,
them to approch the roome (yet who would advise
Treason should come so neare?) there would be then
No place left for excuse.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: How strong are they?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Weake, considering
the enterprize; they are but few in number,
and those few too, having nothing but
their resolutions considerable about them.
A Troope indeed design'd to suffer what
they come to execute.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Who are they are thus wearie of their lives?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Their names I cannot give you.
For those hee sent for, hee did still receive
at a back doore, and so dismist them too.
But I doe thinke Ziriff is one.—

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Take heed! I shall suspect thy hate to others,
not thy love to mee, begot this service;
This Treason thou thy selfe do'st say
has but an houres age, and I can give accompt
of him, beyond that time.— Brother, in the little Tower
where now Aglaura's prisoner,
you shall finde him; bring him along,
hee yet doth stand untainted in my thoughts,
and to preserve him so,
hee shall not stirre out of my eyes command
till this great cloud be over.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Sir, 'twas the Prince who first—

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I know all that! urge it no more!
I love the man;
and 'tis with paine, wee doe suspect,
where wee doe not dislike:
th'art sure hee will have some,
and that they will come to night?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: As sure as night will come it selfe.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Get all our Guards in readinesse, we will our selfe
disperse them afterwards; and both be sure
to weare your thoughts within: Ile act the rest:

sp.speaker: 2. COURT.
sp.l: Well.— If there be not some great storme towards,
nere trust mee; Whisper (Court Thunder) is in
everie corner, and there has beene to day
about the Towne a murmuring
and buzzing, such as men use to make,
when they doe feare to vent their feares;

sp.speaker: 1. COURT.
sp.p: True, and all the States-men hang downe their heads, like full ear'd corne; two of them
sp.l: where I sup't, ask't what time of night it was,
and when 'twas told them, started, as if
they had beene to run a race.

sp.speaker: 2. COURT.
sp.p: The King too (if you marke him,) doth faigne mirth and jollitie, but through them both,
sp.l: flashes of discontent, and anger make escapes:

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Gentlemen! 'tis pittie heav'n
design'd you not to make the Almanacks.
You ghesse so shrewdly by the ill aspects,
or neere conjunctions of the great ones,
at what's to come still; that without all doubt
the Countrey had beene govern'd wholly by you,
and plow'd and reap'd accordingly; for mee,
I understand this mysterie as little
as the new Love, and as I take it too,
'tis much about the Time that everie thing
but Owles, and Lovers take their rest;
Goodnight, Philan— away—

sp.speaker: 1. COURT.
sp.l: 'Tis early yet; let's goe on the Queens side
and foole a little; I love to warme my selfe
before I goe to bed, it does beget
handsome and sprightly thoughts, and makes
our dreames halfe solid pleasures.

sp.speaker: 2. COURT.
sp.l: Agreed: agreed:

div.head: SCENA I.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: COuldst thou not finde out Ziriff?

sp.speaker: 1. COURT.
sp.l: Not speake with him my Lord;
yet I sent in by severall men.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: I wonder Iolas meets us not here too.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: 'Tis strange, but let's on now how ere,
when Fortunes, honour, life, and all's in doubt
bravely to dare, is bravely to get out.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Betrai'd! betrai'd!

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Shift for your selfe Sir, and let us alone,
wee will secure your way, and make our owne.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Follow Lords, and see quick execution done,
leave not a man alive.
Who treads on fire, and does not put it out,
Disperses feare in many sparks of doubt.

div.stage: Enter Conspirators, and the Guard upon them.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Stand friends, an equall partie—

div.stage: Three of the Conspirators fall, and three of the Kings side: Orsames and Philan kill the rest.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Brave Orsames, 'tis pleasure to dye neere thee.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Talke not of dying Philan, we will live,
and serve the noble Prince agen; we are alone,
off then with thy disguise, and throw it in the bushes;
quick, quick; before the torrent comes upon us:
wee shall be streight good Subjects, and I despaire not
of reward for this nights service: so.—
wee two now kill'd our friends! 'tis hard,
but 'tmust be so.

div.stage: Enter Ariaspes, Jolas, two Courtiers, part of the Guard.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Follow! Follow!

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Yes; so you may now, y'are not likely to overtake.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Orsames, and Philan, how came you hither?

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: The neerest way it seemes, you follow'd (thank you)
as if 'thad beene through quicksets:

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: 's Death have they all escap'd?

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Not all, two of them wee made sure;
but they cost deare, looke here else.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Is the Prince there?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: They are both Princes I thinke,
they fought like Princes I am sure.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Stephines, and Odîris— we trifle.
Which way tooke the rest?

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Two of them are certainly here abouts.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Upon my life they swam the river;
some streight to horse, and follow ore the bridge;
you, and I my Lord, will search this place a little better.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Your Highnesse will I hope remember, who were
the men were in—

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Oh! feare not, your Mistresse shall know y'are valiant.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Philan! if thou lov'st mee, let's kill them upon the place.

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Fie: thou now art wild indeed;
thou taught'st mee to be wise first,
and I will now keepe thee so.— Follow, follow.

div.stage: The Prince comes and knocks within.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Madam!

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: What wretch is this that thus usurps
upon the priviledge of Ghosts, and walks
at mid-night?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Aglaura.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Betray mee not
my willing sense too soone, yet if that voyce
be false.—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Open faire Saint, and let mee in.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: It is the Prince—
as willingly as those
that cannot sleepe doe light; welcome (Sir,)
welcome above.—
Blesse mee, what meanes this unsheath'd minister of death?
if, Sir, on mee quick Justice be to passe,
why this? absence alas, or such strange lookes
as you now bring with you would kill as soone:

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Softly! for I, like a hard hunted Deere,
have only hearded here; and though the crie
reach not our eares, yet am I follow'd close:
ô my heart! since I saw thee,
Time has beene strangely Active, and begot
a Monstrous issue of unheard of Storie:
Sit; thou shalt have it all! nay, sigh not.
such blasts will hinder all the passage;
Do'st thou remember, how wee parted last?

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Can I forget it Sir?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: That word of parting was ill plac'd, I sweare,
it may be ominous; but do'st thou know
into whose hands I gave thee?

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Yes into Ziriff Sir.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: That Ziriff was thy brother, brave Zorannes
preserv'd by miracle in that sad day
thy father fell, and since thus in disguise,
waiting his just revenge.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: You doe amaze me, Sir.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: And must doe more, when I tell all the Storie.
The King, the jealous King, knew of the marriage,
and when thou thought'st thy selfe by my direction,
thou wert his Prisoner;
unlesse I would renounce all right,
and cease to love thee, (o strange, and fond request!)
immur'd thou must have beene in some sad place,
and lockt for ever, from Thersames sight.
For ever— and that unable to indure
this night, I did attempt his life.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Was it well done Sir?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: O no! extremely Ill!
for to attempt and not to act was poore:
here the dead-doing Law, (like ill-paid Souldiers)
leaves the side 'twas on, to joyne with power.
Royall villany now will looke so like to Justice,
that the times to come and curious posteritie,
will finde no difference: weep'st thou Aglaura?
come, to bed my Love!
and wee will there mock Tyrannie, and Fate,
those softer houres of pleasure, and delight,
that like so many single pearles, should have
adorn'd our thread of life, wee will at once,
by Loves mysterious power, and this nights help
contract to one, and make but one rich draught
of all.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: What meane you Sir?

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: To make my selfe incapable of miserie,
by taking strong preservative of happinesse:
I would this night injoy thee:

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Doe: Sir, doe what you will with mee,
for I am too much yours, to deny the right
however claim'd— but—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: But what Aglaura?

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Gather not roses in a wet and frowing houre,
they'll lose their sweets then, trust mee they will Sir.
What pleasure can Love take to play his game out,
when death must keepe the Stakes—
harke Sir— grave bringers, and last minutes are at hand,
hide, hide your selfe, for Loves sake hide your selfe.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: As soone the Sunne may hide himselfe, as I.
The Prince of Persia hide himselfe?—

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: O talke not Sir; the Sunne does hide himselfe
when night and blacknesse comes—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Never sweet Ignorance, he shines in th'other world then;
and so shall I, if I set here in glorie:
Enter
yee hastie seekers of life.
Sorannez.—

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: My brother!
If all the joy within mee come not out,
to give a welcome to so deare an object,
excuse it Sir; sorrow locks up all doores.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: If there be such a Toy about you, Sister,
keep't for your selfe, or lend it to the Prince;
there is a dearth of that Commoditie,
and you have made it Sir. Now?
what is the next mad thing you meane to doe?
will you stay here? when all the Court's beset
like to a wood at a great hunt, and busie mischiefe hastes
to be in view, and have you in her power—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: To mee all this—
for great griefe's deafe as well as it is dumbe,
and drives no trade at all with Counsell: (Sir)
why doe you not Tutor one that has the Plague,
and see if hee will feare an after ague fit;
such is all mischiefe now to mee; there is none left
is worth a thought, death is the worst, I know,
and that compar'd to shame, does looke more lovely now
than a chaste Mistresse, set by common woman—
and I must court it Sir?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: No wonder if that heav'n for sake us, when wee leave our selves:
what is there done should feed such high despaire?
were you but safe—

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Deare (Sir) be rul'd,
if love, be love, and magick too,
(as sure it is where it is true;)
wee then shall meet in absence, and in spight
of all divorce, freely enjoy together,
what niggard Fate thus peevishly denies.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Yea: but if pleasures be themselves but dreames,
what then are the dreames of these to men?
that monster, Expectation, will devoure
all that is within our hope or power,
and ere wee once can come to shew, how rich
wee are, wee shall be poore,
shall wee not Sorannez?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: I understand not this,
in times of envious penurie (such as these are)
to keepe but love alive is faire, wee should not thinke
of feasting him: come (Sir)
here in these lodgings is a little doore,
that leads unto another; that againe,
unto a vault, that has his passage under
the little river, opening into the wood;
from thence 'tis but some few minutes easie businesse
unto a Servants house of mine (who for his faith
and honestie, hereafter must
looke big in Storie) there you are safe however;
and when this Storme has met a little calme,
what wild desire dares whisper to it selfe,
you may enjoy, and at the worst may steale:

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: What shall become of thee Aglaura then?
shall I leave thee their rages sacrifice?
and like dull Sea-men threatned with a storme,
throw all away, I have, to save my selfe.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Can I be safe when you are not? my Lord!
knowes love in us divided happinesse?
am I the safer for your being here?
can you give that you have not for your selfe?
my innocence is my best guard, and that your stay
betraying it unto suspition, takes away.
If you did love mee?—

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Growes that in question? then 'tis time to part:—
when wee shall meet againe Heav'n onely knowes,
and when wee shall I know we shall be old:
Love does not calculate the common way,
Minutes are houres there, and the houres are dayes,
each day's a yeare, and everie yeare an age;
what will this come to thinke you?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Would this were all the ill,
for these are prettie little harmlesse nothings;
Times horse runs full as fast, hard borne and curb'd,
as in his full carreere, loose-rain'd and spurr'd:
come, come, let's away.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Happinesse, such as men lost in miserie
would wrong in naming, 'tis so much above them.
All that I want of it, all you deserve,
Heav'n send you in my absence.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: And miserie, such as wittie malice would
lay out in curses, on the thing it hates,
Heav'n send mee in the stead, if when y'are gone
I welcome it, but for your sake alone.—

div.stage: Leads him out, and enters up out of the vault.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.p: Stir not from hence, Sir, till you heare from me so goodnight deere Prince.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: Goodnight deere friend.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: When wee meet next all this will but advance—
Joy never feasts so high,
as when the first course is of miserie.

div.head: SCENA I.

sp.speaker: 1. COURT
sp.l: BY this light— a brave Prince,
sp.p: hee made no more of the Guard, than they would of a Taylor on a Maske night, that has refus'd trusting before.

sp.speaker: 2. COURT.
sp.l: Hee's as Active as he is valiant too;
did'st mark him how hee stood like all the points
o'th' Compasse, and as good Pictures,
had his eyes, towards everie man.

sp.speaker: 3. COURT.
sp.l: And his sword too,
all th'other side walk up and downe the Court now,
as if they had lost their way, and stare,
like Grey-hounds, when the Hare has taken the furze,

sp.speaker: 1. COURT.
sp.l: Right,
and have more troubles about'em
than a Serving-man that has forgot his message
when hee's come upon the place.—

sp.speaker: 2. COURT.
sp.l: Yonder's the King within, chafing, and swearing
like an old Falconer upon the first flight
of a young Hawke, when some Clowne
has taken away the quarrie from her;
and all the Lords stand round about him,
as if hee were to be baited, with much more feare,
and at much more distance,
than a Countrey Gentlewoman sees the Lions the first time:
looke: hee's broke loose.—

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Finde him; or by Osiris selfe, you all are Traitours;
and equally shall pay to Justice; a single man,
and guiltie too, breake through you all!

sp.speaker: ZIR
sp.l: Confidence!
(thou paint of women, and the States-mans wisdome,
valour for Cowards, and of the guilties Innocence,)
assist mee now.
Sir, send these Starers off:
I have some businesse will deserve your privacie.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Leave us.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: How the villaine swells vpon us?—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Not to punish thought,
or keepe it long upon the wrack of doubt,
know Sir,
That by corruption of the waiting woman,
the common key of Secrets, I have found
the truth at last, and have discover'd all:
the Prince your Sonne was by Aglaura's meanes,
convey'd last night unto the Cypresse Grove,
through a close vault that opens in the lodgings:
hee does intend to joyne with Carimania,
but ere hee goes, resolves to finish all
the rites of Love, and this night meanes
to steale what is behinde.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: How good is Heav'n unto mee!
that when it gave mee Traitours for my Subjects,
would lend mee such a Servant!

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: How just (Sir) rather,
that would bestow this Fortune on the poore.
and where your bountie had made debt so infinite
that it grew desperate, their hope to pay it—

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Enough of that, thou do'st but gently chide
mee for a fault, that I will mend; for I
have beene too poore, and low in my rewards
unto thy vertue: but to our businesse;
the question is, whether wee shall rely
upon our Guards agen?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: By no meanes Sir:
hope on his future fortunes, or their Love
unto his person, has so sicklied ore
their resolutions, that wee must not
trust them.
Besides, it were but needlesse here;
hee passes through the vault alone, and I
my selfe durst undertake that businesse,
if that were all, but there is something else,
this accident doth prompt my zeale to serve you in.
I know you love Aglaura (Sir) with passion,
and would enjoy her; I know besides
shee loves him so, that whosoere shall bring
the tidings of his death, must carrie back
the newes of hers, so that your Justice (Sir)
must rob your hope: but there is yet a way—

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Here! take my heart; for I have hitherto
too vainly spent the treasure of my love,
Ile have it coyn'd streight into friendship all,
and make a present to thee.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: If any part of this rich happinesse,
(fortune prepares now for you) shall owe it selfe
unto my weake endevours, I have enough.
Aglaura without doubt this night expects
the Prince, and why
you should not then supply his place by stealth,
and in disguise—

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I apprehend thee Ziriff,
but there's difficultie—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Who trades in Love must be an adventurer, (Sir)
but here is scarce enough to make the pleasure dearer:
I know the Cave; your Brother and my selfe
with Iolas, (for those w'are sure doe hate him,)
with some few chosen more betimes will wait
the Princes passing through the vault; if hee
comes first, hee's dead; and if it be your selfe,
wee will conduct you to the chamber doore,
and stand 'twixt you and danger afterwards.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: I have conceiv'd of Joy, and am growne great:
Till I have safe deliverance, time's a cripple
and goes on crutches.— as for thee my Ziriff,
I doe here entertaine a friendship with thee,
shall drowne the memorie of all patternes past;
wee will oblige by turnes; and that so thick,
and fast, that curious studiers of it,
shall not once dare to cast it up, or say
by way of ghesse, whether thou or I
remaine the debtors, when wee come to die.

div.stage: Enter Semanthe, Orithie, Philan, Orsames, Lords and Ladies.

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.l: Is the Queene ready to come out?

sp.speaker: PHI.
sp.l: Not yet sure, the Kings brother is but newly entred;

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: Come my Lord, the Song then.

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.l: The Song.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: A vengeance take this love, it spoyles a voyce
worse than the losing of a maiden-head.
I have got such a cold with rising
and walking in my shirt a nights, that
a Bittorne whooping in a reed is better musike.

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.l: This modestie becomes you as ill, my Lord,
as wooing would us women: pray, put's not to't.

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: Nay Ladies, you shall finde mee,
as free, as the Musicians of the woods
themselves; what I have, you shall not need to call for,
nor shall it cost you any thing.

lg.l: WHy so pale and wan fond Lover?
Prithee why so pale?
Will, when looking well can't move her,
Looking ill prevaile?
Prithee why so pale?
Why so dull and mute young Sinner?
Prithee why so mute?
Will, when speaking well can't win her,
Saying nothing doo't?
Prithee why so mute?
Quit, quit, for shame, this will not move
This cannot take her;
If of her selfe shee will not Love,
Nothing can make her,
The Devill take her.

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.l: I should have ghest, it had been the issue of
your braine, if I had not beene told so;

sp.speaker: ORS.
sp.l: A little foolish counsell (Madam) I gave a friend
of mine foure or five yeares agoe, when he was
falling into a Consumption.—

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: Which of all you have seene the faire prisoner
since shee was confinde?

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: I have Madam.

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: And how behaves shee now her selfe?

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: As one that had intrench'd so deepe in Innocence,
shee fear'd no enemies, beares all quietly,
and smiles at Fortune, whil'st shee frownes on her.

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: So gallant! I wonder where the beautie lies
that thus inflames the royall bloud?

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.l: Faces, Madam, are like bookes, those that doe study them
know best, and to say truth, 'tis still
much as it pleases the Courteous Reader.

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: These Lovers sure are like Astronomers,
that when the vulgar eye discovers, but
a Skie above, studded with some few Stars,
finde out besides strange fishes, birds, and beasts.

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: As men in sicknesse scortch'd into a raving
doe see the Devill, in all shapes and formes,
when standers by wondring, aske where, and when;
So they in Love, for all's but feaver there,
and madnesse too.

sp.speaker: ORB.
sp.l: That's too severe Semanthe;
but wee will have your reasons in the parke;
are the doores open through the Gardens?

sp.speaker: LO.
sp.l: The King has newly led the way.

div.stage: Enter Ariaspes: Ziriff, with a warrant sealed.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Thou art a Tyrant, Ziriff: I shall die with joy.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: I must confesse my Lord; had but the Princes ills
prov'd ●…eight, and not thus dangerous,
hee should have ow'd to mee, at least I would
have laid a claime unto his safetie; and
like Physicians, that doe challenge right
in Natures cures, look'd for reward and thanks;
but since 'twas otherwise, I thought it best
●…o save my selfe, and then to save the State.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: 'Twas wisely done.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Safely I'me sure, my Lord! you know 'tis not
●…ur custome, where the Kings dislike, once swells to hate,
there to ingage our selves; Court friendship
is a Cable, that in stormes is ever cut,
and I made bold with it; here is the warrant seal'd
and for the execution of it, if you thinke
wee are not strong enough, wee may have
〈◊〉, for him the King did name.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: And him I would have named.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: But is hee not too much the Prince's (Sir?)

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Hee is as lights in Scenes at Masques,
what glorious shew so ere hee makes without,
I that set him there, know why, and how;
but here hee is.—
Come Iolas. and since the Heav'ns decreed,
the man whom thou should'st envie, should be such,
That all men else must doo't; be not asham'd
thou once we●… guiltie of it;
but blesse them, that they give thee now a meanes,
to make a friendship with him, and vouchsafe
to finde thee out a way to love, where well
thou could'st not hate.

sp.speaker: JO●….
sp.l: What meanes my Lord?

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Here, here hee stands that has preserv'd us all!
that sacrific'd unto a ●…u lique good,
(the dearest private good wee mortalls have)
Frien●…hip: gave into ourarmes the Prince,
when nothing but the sword (perchance a ruine)
was left to doe it.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: How could I chide my love, and my ambition now,
that thrust mee upon such a quarrell? here I doe vow—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Hold, doe not vow my Lord, let it deserve it first;
and yet (if Heav'n blesse honest mens intents)
'tis not impossible.
My Lord, you will be pleas'd to informe him in particulars,
I must be gone.—
the King I feare already has beene left
too long alone.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Stay— the houre and place.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Eleven, under the Tarras walke;
I will not faile you there.
I had forgot:—
●…may be, the small remainder of those lost men
that were of the Conspiracie, will come along with him:
'twere best to have some chosen of the Guard
within our call—

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Honest, and carefull Ziriff:
how now Planet strooke?—

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: This Ziriff will grow great with all the world.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Shallow man! short sightedder than Travellers in mists,
or women that outlive themselves; do'st thou not see,
that whil'st hee does prepare a Tombe with one hand
for his friend, hee digs a Grave with th'other for himselfe?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: How so?

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Do'st thinke hee shall not feele the weight of this,
as well as poore Thersames?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Shall wee then kill him too at the same instant?

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: And say, the Prince made an unluckie thrust.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Dull, dull, hee must not dye so uselesly.
As when wee wipe of filth from any place,
wee throw away the thing that made it clea●…e,
so this once done, hee's gone.
Thou know'st the People love the Prince, to their rage
something the State must offer up; who fitter
than thy rivall and my enemy?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Rare! our witnesse will be taken.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Pish! let mee alone.
The Giants that made mountaines ladders,
and thought to take great Iove by force, were fooles:
not hill on hill, but plot on plot, does make
us sit above, and laugh at all below us.—

div.stage: Enter Aglaura, and a Singing Boy.

sp.speaker: BOY.
sp.l: Madam, 'twill make you melancholly,
Ile sing the Prince's Song, that's sad enough.

sp.speaker: AG●….
sp.l: What you will Sir.

lg.l: NO, no, faire Heretique, it needs must bee
But an ill Love in mee,
And worse for thee.
For were it in my Power,
To love thee now this hower,
More than I did the last;
I would then so fall,
I might not Love at all;
Love that can flow, and can admit increase,
Admits as well an Ebb, and may grow lesse.
True Love is still the same; the torrid Zones,
And those more frigid ones,
It must not know:
For Love growne cold or hot,
Is Lust, or Friendship, not
The thing wee have;
For that's a flame would die,
Held downe, or up to high:
Then thinke I love more than I ca●… expresse,
And would love more, could I but love thee lesse.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Leave mee! for to a Soule, so out of Tune
as mine is now; nothing is harmony:
when once the maine-spring, Hope, is falne into
disorder; no wonder, if the lesser wheeles,
Desire, and Ioy, stand still; my thoughts like Bees
when they have lost their King, wander
confusedly up and downe, and settle no where.
Orithie, flie! flie the roome,
as thou would'st shun the habitations
which Spirits haunt, or where thy nearer friends
walk after death; here is not only Love,
●…ut Loves plague too— mis-fortune; and so high,
that it is sure infectious!

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.p: Madam, so much more miserable am I this way than you, that should I pitie you, I should forget my selfe:
sp.l: my sufferings are such, that with lesse patience
you may endure your owne, than give mine Audience.
There is that difference, that you may make
yours none at all, but by considering mine!

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: O speake them quickly then! the marriage day
to passionate Lovers never was more welcome,
than any kinde of ease would be to mee now.

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.l: Could they be spoke, they were not then so great.
I love, and dare not say I love; dare not hope,
what I desire; yet still too must desire—
and like a starving man brought to a feast,
and made say grace, to what he nere shall taste,
be thankfull after all, and kisse the hand,
that made the wound thus deepe.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: 'Tis hard indeed, but with what unjust scales,
thou took'st the weight of our mis-fortunes,
be thine owne Judge now.
thou mourn'st for losse of that thou never hadst,
or if thou hadst a losse, it never was
of a Thersames.
would'st thou not thinke a Merchant mad, Orithie?
if thou shouldst see him weepe, and teare his haire,
because hee brought not both the Indies home?
and wouldst not thinke his sorrowes verie just,
if having fraught his ship with some rich Treasure,
hee sunke i'th' verie Port? This is our case.

sp.speaker: ORI.
sp.l: And doe you thinke there is such odds in it?
would Heaven we women could as easily change
our fortunes as ('tis said) wee can our minds.
I cannot (Madam) thinke them miserable,
that have the Princes Love.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Hee is the man then—
blush not Orithie, 'tis a sinne to blush
for loving him, though none at all to love him.
I can admit of rivalship without
a jealousie— nay shall be glad of it:
wee two will sit, and thinke, and thinke, and sigh,
and sigh, and talke of love— and of Thersames.
Thou shalt be praising of his wit, while I
admire he governes it so well:
like this thing, said thus, th'other thing thus done,
and in good language him for these adore,
while I want words to doo't, yet doe it more.
Thus will wee doe, till death it selfe shall us
divide, and then whose fate 'tshall be to die
first of the two, by legacie shall all
her love bequeath, and give her stock to her
that shall survive; for no one stock can serve,
to love Thersames so as hee'll deserve.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: What have wee here impossibilitie?
a constant night, and yet within the roome
that, that can make the day before the Sunne?
silent Aglaura too?

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: I know not what to say:
●…s't to your pitie, or your scorne, I owe
the favour of this visit (Sir?) for such
my fortune is, it doth deserve them both:

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: And such thy beautie is, that it makes good
all Fortunes, sorrow lookes lovely here;
and there's no man, that would not entertaine
his griefes as friends, were hee but sure they'd shew
no worse upon him— but I forget my selfe,
I came to chide.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.p: If I have sinn'd so high, that yet my punishment equalls not my crime,
sp.l: doe Sir; I should be loth to die in debt
to Justice, how ill soere I paid
the scores of Love.—

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.p: And those indeed thou hast but paid indifferently to mee, I did deserve at least faire death,
sp.l: not to be murthered thus in private:
that was too cruell, Mistresse.
And I doe know thou do'st repent, and wilt
yet make mee satisfaction:

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: What satisfaction Sir?
I am no monster, never had two hearts;
One is by holy vowes anothers now,
and could I give it you, you would not take it,
for'tis alike impossible for mee,
to love againe, as you love Perjurie.
O Sir! consider, what a flame love is.
If by rude meanes you thinke to force a light,
that of it selfe it would not freely give,
you blow it out, and leave your selfe i'th' darke.
The Prince once gone, you may as well perswade
the light to stay behinde, when the Sun posts
to th'other world, as mee; alas! wee two,
have mingled soules more than two meeting brooks;
and whosoever is design'd to be
the murtherer of my Lord, (as sure there is,
has anger'd heav'n so farre, that 'tas decreed
him to encrease his punishment that way)
would hee but search the heart, when hee has done,
hee there would finde Aglaura murther'd too.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Thou hast ●…come mee, mov'd so handsomely
for pitie, that I will dis-inherit
the elder brother, and from this houre be
thy Convert, not thy Lover.—
Ziriff, dispatch away—
and hee that brings newes of the Prince's welfare,
looke that hee have the same reward, wee had decreed
to him, brought tidings of his death.
'Tmust be a busie and bold hand, that would
unlinke a chaine the Gods themselves have made:
peace to thy Thoughts: Aglaura—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: What ere he sayes beleeve him not Aglaura:
for lust and rage ride high within him now:
hee knowes Thersames made th'escape from hence,
and does conceale it only for his ends:
for by the favour of mistake and night,
hee hopes t'enjoy thee in the Prince's roome;
I shall be mist— else I would tell thee more;
But thou mayest ghesse, for our condition
admits no middle wayes, either wee must
send them to Graves, or lie our selves in dust:—

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis a strange Act thought puts me now upon;
yet sure my brother meant the selfe same thing,
and my Thersames would have done't for mee:
to take his life, that seekes to take away
the life of Life, (honour from mee;) and from
the world, the life of honour, Thersames;
must needs be something sure, of kin to Justice.
If I doe faile, th'attempt howere was brave,
and I shall have at worst a handsome grave—

div.stage: Semanthe steps back, Jolas stayes her.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: What? are we growne, Semanthe, night, and day?
Must one still vanish when the other comes?
Of all that ever Love did yet bring forth
(and 't has beene fruitfull too,) this is
the strangest Issue.—

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: What my Lord?

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Hate, Semanthe.

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: You doe mistake, if I doe shun you, 'tis,
as bashfull Debtors shun their Creditors,
I cannot pay you in the selfe same coyne,
and am asham'd to offer any other.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: It is ill done, Semanthe, to plead bankrupt,
when with such ease you may be out of debt;
In loves dominions, native commoditie
is currant payment, change is all the Trade,
and heart for heart, the richest merchandize.

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: 'Twould here be meane my Lord, since mine would prove
In your hands but a Counterfeit, and yours in mine
worth nothing; Sympathy, not greatnesse,
makes those Jewells rise in value.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Sympathy! ô teach but yours to love then,
and two so rich no mortall ever knew.

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: That heart would Love but ill that must be taught,
such fires as these still kindle of themselves.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: In such a cold, and frozen place, as is
thy breast? how should they kindle of themselves
Semanthe?

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: Aske? how the Flint can carrie fire within?
'tis the least miracle that Love can doe:

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Thou art thy selfe the greatest miracle,
for thou art faire to all perfection,
and yet do'st want the greatest part of beautie,
Kindnesse; thy crueltie (next to thy selfe,)
above all things on earth takes up my wonder.

sp.speaker: SEM.
sp.l: Call not that crueltie, which is our fate,
beleeve me Iolas, the honest Swaine
that from the brow of some steepe cliffe far off,
beholds a ship labouring in vaine against
the boysterous and unruly Elements, ne're had
lesse power, or more desire to help than I;
at everie sigh, I die, and everie looke,
does move; and any passion you will have
but Love, I have in store: I will be angrie,
quarrell with destinie, and with my selfe
that 'tis no better; be melancholy;
And (though mine owne disasters well might plead
to be in chiefe,) yours only shall have place,
Ile pitie, and (if that's too low) Ile grieve,
as for my sinnes, I cannot give you ease;
all this I doe, and this I hope will prove
'tis greater Torment not to love, than Love.—

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: So perishing Sailours pray to stormes,
and so they heare agen. So men
with death about them, looke on Physitians that
have given them o're, and so they turne away:
Two fixed Stars that keepe a constant distance,
and by lawes made with themselves must know
no motion excentrick, may meet as soone as wee:
The anger that the foolish Sea does shew,
when it does brave it out, and rore against
a stubborne rock that still denies it passage,
is not so vaine and fruitlesse, as my prayers.
Yee mightie Powers of Love and Fate, where is
your Justice here? It is thy part (fond Boy)
when thou do'st finde one wounded heart, to make
the other so, but if thy Tyranny
be such, that thou wilt leave one breast to hate,
If wee must live, and this survive,
how much more cruell's Fate?—

div.head: SCENA I.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: A Glorious night!

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Pray Heav'n it prove so.
Are wee not there yet?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: 'Tis about this hollow.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: How now! what region are we got into?
th'Enheritance of night;
Are wee not mistaken a turning Ziriff,
and stept into some melancholy Devils Territorie?
Sure 'tis a part of the first Chaos,
that would endure no change.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: No matter Sir, 'tis as proper for our purpose,
as the Lobbie for the waiting womans.
Stay you here, Ile move a little backward,
and so wee shall be sure to put him past
retreat: you know the word if't be the Prince.
sp.stage: Goes to the mouth of the Cave.
sp.l: Here Sir, follow mee, all's quiet yet.—

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Hee is not come then?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: KING.
sp.l: Where's Ariaspes?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Waiting within.

div.stage: Hee leads him on, steps behinde him, gives the false word, they kill the King.

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: I doe not like this waiting,
nor this fellowes leaving us.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: This place does put odd thoughts into thee,
then thou art in thine owne nature too, as jealous
as either Love, or Honor: Come, weare thy sword in readines,
and thinke how neere wee are a crowne.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Revenge!
So let's drag him to the light, and search
his pockets, there may be papers there that will
discover the rest of the Conspiratours.
Iol●…s, your hand—

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Whom have wee here? the King!

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Yes, and Zorrannes too, Illo! hoe!—
Unarme them.
D'ee stare?
This for my Fathers injuries and mine:
sp.stage: Points to the Kings dead body.
sp.l: halfe Love, halfe Duties Sacrifice,
this— for the noble Prince, an offering to friendship:

sp.speaker: JOL.
sp.l: Basely! and tamely—

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Nothing— kill'd a Traytour,
So— away with them, and leaves us,
Pasithas be onely you in call.

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: What do'st thou pawse?
hast thou remorse already murtherer?

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: No foole: 'tis but a difference I put
betwixt the crimes: Orbella is our quarrell;
and I doe hold it fit, that love should have
a nobler way of Justice, than Revenge
or Treason; follow mee out of the wood,
and thou shalt be Master of this againe:
and then, best arme and title take it.
sp.stage: They goe out and enter agen.
sp.l: There—

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Extremely good! Nature tooke paines I sweare,
the villaine and the brave are mingled handsomly.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: 'Twas Fate that tooke it, when it decreed
wee two should meet, nor shall they mingle now
wee are brought together strait to part.—

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Some Devill sure has borrowed this shape.
my sword ne're stay'd thus long to finde an entrance.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: To guiltie men, all that appeares is Devill,
come Trifler, come.—

sp.speaker: ARI.
sp.l: Whither, whither, thou fleeting Coward life?
Bubble of Time, Natures shame, stay; a little, stay!
till I have look'd my selfe into revenge,
and star'd this Traytour to a carcasse first.
— It will not be:—
the Crowne, the Crowne, too
now is lost, for ever lost— oh!—
Ambition's, but an Ignis fatuus, I see
misleading fond mortalitie,
That hurries us about, and sets us downe
Just— where— wee— first— begun—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: What a great spreading mightie thing this was,
and what a nothing now? how soone poore man
vanishes into his noone-tide shadow?
but hopes o're fed have seldome better done:—
Take up this lump of vanitie, and honour,
and carrie it the back way to my lodging,
there may be use of States-men, when th'are dead:
So.— for the Cittadell now, for in such times
as these, when the unruly multitude
is up in swarmes, and no man knowes which way
they'll take, 'tis good to have retreat.

sp.speaker: THER.
sp.l: The Dog-star's got up high, it should be late:
and sure by this time everie waking eare,
and watchfull eye is charm'd; and yet mee thought
a noyse of weapons strucke my eare just now.
'Twas but my Fancie sure, and were it more,
I would not tread one step, that did not lead
to my Aglaura, stood all his Guard betwixt,
with lightning in their hands;
Danger! thou Dwarfe drest up in Giants clothes,
that shew'st farre off, still greater than thou art:
goe, terrifie the simple, and the guiltie, such
as with false Opticks, still doe looke upon thee.
But fright not Lovers, wee dare looke on thee
in thy worst shape, and meet thee in them too.
Stay— These trees I made my marke, 'tis hereabouts,
— Love guide mee but right this night,
and Lovers shall restore thee back againe
those eyes the Poets tooke so boldly from thee.

div.stage: Aglaura with a torch in one hand, and a dagger in the other.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: How ill this does become this hand, how much worse
this suits with this, one of the two should goe.
The shee within mee sayes, it must be this—
honour sayes this— and honour is Thersames friend.
What is that shee then? it is not a thing
that sets a Price, not upon mee, but on
life in my name, leading mee into doubt,
which when 'tas done, it cannot light mee out.
For feare does drive to Fate, or Fate if wee
doe flie, oretakes, and holds us, till or death,
or infamie, or both doth cease us.—
Ha!— would 'twere in agen.
Antiques and strange mishapes,
such as the Porter to my Soule, mine Eye,
was ne're acquainted with, Fancie lets in,
like a distracted multitude, by some strange accident
piec'd together, feare now afresh comes on,
and charges Love to home.
— Hee comes— hee comes—
sp.p: woman, if thou would'st be the Subject of mans wonder, not his scorne hereafter,
sp.l: now shew thy selfe.
sp.stage: Enter Prince rising from the vault, shee stabs him two or three times, hee falls, shees goes back to her chamber.
sp.l: Sudden and fortunate.
My better Angell sure did both infuse
a strength, and did direct it.

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: Aglaura!

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: Brother—

sp.speaker: ZIR.
sp.l: The same.
So slow to let in such a long'd for Guest?
must Joy stand knocking Sister, come, prepare,
prepare.—
The King of Persia's comming to you strait!
the King!— marke that.

sp.speaker: AGL.
sp.l: I thought how poore the Joyes you brought with you,
were in respect of those that were with mee:
